I dunno, sub-orbital flight doesn't really excite me all that much.  I'm a big space nut, but it's like I almost don't consider anything below orbital velocity to an actual spaceflight.  People can argue and disagree but that's just kind of how I've always felt about it.  It isn't so much the "height" of getting to space that's difficult, it's always been getting the velocity once you're above the atmosphere that's always been the trick.  A balloon flight can do the same thing like that one skydiver did a few years back without any rocket.

Another great vid. I have come to mostly renounce tribalism, in large part because of your discussions. The thing that ticked me off and set me on that path is some of the company statements that implied they were neck-and-neck with SpaceX, not acknowledging the sub-orbital difference. It got worse with almost all news coverage being glowing, and also not covering the sob-orbital thing. That part not Blue Origin's fault, pretty much. News reporting is so superficial and sloppy. Worse is the fans of BO frequently lying-by-ommision when boasting about BO's successes.
The worst is ULA. A recent statement said SpaceX's reusability was no big deal, they would have it soon, by returning the engines only. Trouble is, that's only a path they are considering doing, no real work underway. As far as I know. Also unhappy with the enormous amount of tax dollars they get. I did pay attention to your vid on SpaceX vs NASA - good info I didn't know! But still too much.
So I 'm happy to have BO progressing to Big Glenn. Impressive rocket engine. Yes, the more rocket companies, the better. Even ULA.

I get Ford versus Chevy but rocket competition between these companies is all in the minds of the fanboy section of the audience. SpaceX and Blue Origin are not the same kind of companies. They do different things.
Their original motivation to start making rockets is to be applauded and supported. It doesn't matter what accomplishments have been made, what the rate of progress is or what plans for future efforts have been announced. They are both moving forward.
I am thrilled that these two high visibility companies are developing launch technologies. Technological success breeds more technological success. Their differing visions and plans currently offer no competition to each other, each proceeding on it's chosen mission without distractions.
I was born before Sputnik and I am thrilled to see this resurgence of Space Interest! We were lost in the doldrums for so long.
So clean,  no smoking flames.
Brought to you by Lex Luthor.

Re: BE-4 vs Raptor, there are two reasons why the BE-4 may have a lower chamber pressure than the Raptor. The first reason is that the Raptor is a full flow staged combustion engine it can reacher higher pressures with less harmful conditions reaching the turbo-pumps. Secondly the BE-4 is engaging in gradatim ferociter, the BE-4 is the first stage of a reusable booster that is aiming to be reusable many times on the first flight,. They have deliberately not designed a vehicles and rocket which require bleeding edge performance to work, once operating the engines can always be upgraded, remember it is the cost of the vehicle, how many times you can use it and how much maintenance it requires that is important not fuel efficiency.
